jobs.name: Jobs
jobs.description: Here are the places I've worked. I included some of the older collaborations I was a part of, because of the lessons I learned and being part of a team.

list.name: Zehlm
list.title: Senior Full-Stack Developer
list.description:
At the beginning of working for Zehlm, I took on small projects. By the end of it, though, I was implementing large sections and trusted with wide swathes of discretion. My responsibilities included:

  • Implementing APIs
  • Editing php Templates
  • Implementing Secure Login
  • Engineering and Implementing JavaScript Libraries
list.shortDescription: At the beginning of working for Zehlm, I took on small projects. By the end of it, though, I was implementing large sections and trusted with wide swathes of discretion.

I had to both edit PHP templates, and produce clean PHP from scratch at Zehlm.
I had to read and implement clean HTML.
At Zehlm, I produced clean, and correct CSS.
Every once in a while, I would have to implement clean HTACCESS for Zehlm
I implemented MySQL for interacting with databases.

Helped implement a content management system, and a user login (with comments).
E-Commerce Implementation
This had a complex user-login, where different types of user accounts would interact with each other in specific ways.

This is a core tool at Web Apps Actualized, and reduces the use of VCR.js down to a list of functions that act on a container.

list.name: Real-Estate Application
list.title: Front-End Developer
list.description:
This was a terrible experience. I met these guys off of Craigslist, and they were underwater. There was a salesman and a server guy. They passed the reigns to me, and I began working. I sent emails almost daily, with my progress.

I got to the stage of installing it on the server, and the server-side guy didn't understand it, but he refused to talk on the phone about it. He only wanted to email. He threw up his hands and refused to work on it.

It turned out that he hadn't been reading the emails. I had dozens of hours in it at this point. There were plenty of problems with what I had produced... definitely. But after the not reading, and the casting it aside, I left the project.

What I Learned

I learned how important reading communications is, and how important it is to ask questions when you don't understand something. I pressure myself to do this out of the golden rule. I strive to not act as if I already know it all... and to question myself.
list.shortDescription: This is a job I had creating a real-estate website.

list.name: Cheyenne Studios
list.title: Front-End Developer
list.description: This was an awesome experience. They would place orders with me with what they wanted produced. I would knock it out, and assist in the installation.
list.shortDescription: This was an awesome experience. They would place orders with me with what they wanted produced. I would knock it out, and assist in the installation.

Projects.ta: A calendar that asked a server script for a list of events from start-date until end-date.

otherFams.name: Languages
otherFams.description: The computer languages I know. I love computer programming: Thousands of Hours.

list.name: JavaScript
list.title: Lead Engineer
list.description: I've done the most with this language. The coolest thing is a front-end framework (VCR.js) similar in goals to Vue.js.
list.shortDescription: I've done the most with this language. The coolest thing is a front-end framework (VCR.js) similar in goals to Vue.js.

Jobs.ta: I did a lot of heavy lifting in the way of JavaScript Zehlm.
A massive amount of JavaScript. The coolest being the VCR front-end framework.

Languages.ta: PHP is sometimes used to manage which JavaScript libraries are being shipped to the client
Of course, JavaScript can emit HTML and edit the DOM... AND, really, JavaScript is a subset of HTML.
I use JavaScript to edit the CSS classes and IDs of HTML elements.

list.name: PHP
list.title: Lead Engineer
list.description:
PHP is my server side language. People talk trash about PHP, but I like it. I chose it because of the sentence: 'if they discontinued support for php, half the internet would die.' It seemed like a safe choice, in this tech landscape that shifts as much as it does.

I love PHP because it was designed to be a server-side web language. Almost all of the day-to-day operations I need to host a site are *default* global functions. No import necessary. People also don't like the dollar sign on variables... but I can name my variable anything I want, and it doesn't pollute the function namespace.
list.shortDescription: PHP is my server side language. People talk trash about PHP, but I like it. I chose it because of the sentence: 'if they discontinued support for php, half the internet would die.' It seemed like a safe choice, in this tech landscape that shifts as much as it does.

Jobs.ta: I had to both edit PHP templates, and produce clean PHP from scratch at Zehlm.
I love php.

Languages.ta: PHP is sometimes used to manage which JavaScript libraries are being shipped to the client
A massive part of PHP is managing the emission of HTML.
PHP is sometimes used to manage which CSS libraries are being shipped to the client
It seems strange to include HTACCESS with PHP, but I have used PHP to meta-code HTACCESS right much.
PHP interacts with MySQL.
PHP interacts with SQLite.
PHP interacts with PostgreSQL

list.description: For a long time, I dismissed HTML, but I've since grown to know how important it is: especially for SEO and performance. Serving up raw HTML is a necessity for the highest of performance scores.
list.shortDescription: For a long time, I dismissed HTML, but I've since grown to know how important it is: especially for SEO and performance. Serving up raw HTML is a necessity for the highest of performance scores.

CSS and HTML --- Joined at the hip

list.title: Server Manager

list.shortDescription: HTACCESS is a pain. It is convoluted and dense. I'm glad it's there, though. It provide a super necessary service.

Projects.ta: This tool generates appropriate HTACCESS.
I used HTACCESS to make a library version manager. I call it a 'library pipe', where projects can override the default version of a library.

list.name: MySQL
list.title: Expert
list.description: Relational databases! I feel like a data-ninja. For real, though, I've dove deep into MySQL, and created an ORM that renders out a MySQL CRUD interface.
list.shortDescription: Relational databases! I feel like a data-ninja. For real, though, I've dove deep into MySQL, and created an ORM that renders out a MySQL CRUD interface.

Jobs.ta: I implemented MySQL for interacting with databases.
The longest project with WAA (the database manager) focused on dynamically generating MySQL interfaces from table meta-data.

Languages.ta: PHP interacts with MySQL.

Projects.ta: The site generator leverages databases made with the database manager.
This program collects data on a daily basis, and relies heavily on MySQL
I had to connect data from a MySQL database, to data in a PostgreSQL Database.
Although this is a JS library, the Database Manager renders the table-interface-front-ends using this library as a target.

list.name: SQLite
list.description: I have used SQLite a lot. I love it. I love that I can just  copy an SQLite database. I love how it is isolated from other databases. Every once in a while, I'll find myself reaching for some kind of behavior that MySQL has but SQLite doesn't... but all in all, it's an A+ from me.
list.shortDescription: I have used SQLite a lot. I love it. I love that I can just  copy an SQLite database. I love how it is isolated from other databases.

Jobs.ta: I have found great use out of the isolation that SQLite provides.

Languages.ta: PHP interacts with SQLite.

Projects.ta: I use SQLite for a lot of the rendered data in the site generator.
SQLite makes installing the database on new instances a breeze, and it isolates instances from one another.
The database manager can render interfaces into SQLite.

list.name: C++
list.description: The date on this is misleading. It would seem that this would be my best language. That is not the case. I discovered C++ as a kid, and then went on a detour into music. I've ended up using C++ to write math programs, and a few Windows console programs. The one I use every day launches my server, and monitors a folder for commands from my local web apps.
list.shortDescription: C++ was my first foray into computer programming. I'm just a beginner with C++.

Jobs.ta: Windows OS Programs

list.name: Bash
list.description: I am a beginner with Bash... but seeing its connection with Git, I can already understand the appeal.
list.shortDescription: I feel like a computer ninja when I'm using Bash

Jobs.ta: I learned a little Bash to go along with Git.

list.name: Git
list.description: Although git isn't a language per se, I chose to include it here: it is a system, with a series commands, to instruct a computer what to do to manage your. In many ways, I see git as a declarative language, pushed through the command line.
list.shortDescription: The more I use git, the more I love it.
list.linkText: Here is a link to my GitHub

list.shortDescription: I learned a little Haskell to explore functional programming, and used it to write a few factoring programs.

list.name: PostgreSQL
list.description: I have only had one experience with this type of database. I had to tie a PostgreSQL database (from an existing membership login) to a MySQL database (from an existing point-of-sale system). I include it here, to show that when I encounter a new technology, I do what I need to in order to solve my problem.
list.shortDescription: I have only had one experience with this type of database. list.name: Database Manager
list.title: Lead Full-Stack Developer
list.description: This was a massively difficult program to produce. It took many years. Not only is it a database editor... but it establishes a custom type system to bridge from JS to PHP to MySQL. It uses this type data to render an entire CRUD interface from the structure of the table that you design.
list.shortDescription: This was a massively difficult program to produce. It took many years. Not only is it a database editor... but it establishes a custom type system to bridge from JS to PHP to MySQL. It uses this type data to render an entire CRUD interface from the structure of the table that you design.

list.name: RMF.js
list.title: Lead Developer
list.description:
RMF stands for 'Ready Made Form'. Of all the aspects of the Database Manager, this was the hardest to engineer. In retrospect, it seems simple.

This is a JS library that accepts a declarative list of 'RMF Input Objects' and uses it to produce a form, that is easy to collect and reset.
list.shortDescription: This is a JS library that accepts a declarative list of 'RMF Input Objects' and uses it to produce a form, that is easy to collect and reset.

Jobs.ta: The RMF library took over a year to engineer and implement for WAA.

Languages.ta: Although this is a JS library, the Database Manager renders the table-interface-front-ends using this library as a target.

list.name: P-Graph
list.title: Lead Developer
list.description: This was graphing software. I did a lot of studying of parametric equations, and used this tool to help study it.
list.shortDescription: This was graphing software. I did a lot of studying of parametric equations, and used this tool to help study it.

list.name: Block Drop
list.title: Lead Developer
list.description: This was a Tetris clone. It worked! It was sort of fun, but had flaws.
list.shortDescription: This was a Tetris clone. It worked! It was sort of fun, but had flaws.

list.name: Interactive Calendar
list.title: Lead Front-End Developer
list.description: I got an order from the backend for a calendar to display events. I made a calendar that sent a request to the server for any events from start to end. It would get a response, and populate the calendar.
list.shortDescription: I got an order from the backend for a calendar to display events. I made a calendar that sent a request to the server for any events from start to end. It would get a response, and populate the calendar.

Jobs.ta: A calendar that asked a server script for a list of events from start-date until end-date.

list.name: Cheyenne Google Maps
list.title: Lead Front-End Developer
list.description: I got a request to make a library to generalize placing markers on Google Maps. I delivered.
list.shortDescription: I got a request to make a library to generalize placing markers on Google Maps. I delivered.

list.name: Music Store Site
list.title: Lead Developer
list.description: One of my very first websites was a site for a music store. It was ok... not that great.
list.shortDescription: One of my very first websites was a site for a music store. It was ok... not that great.

list.name: File System Manager
list.title: Lead Full-Stack Developer
list.description: This is an in-house program that manages the htdocs folder on my Apache server. It allows you to add, remove, and edit various types of text files. It also includes an html application rendering engine, with small text areas to edit various aspects of the html document.
list.shortDescription: This is an in-house program that manages the htdocs folder on my Apache server. It allows you to add, remove, and edit various types of text files. It also includes an html application rendering engine, with small text areas to edit various aspects of the html document.

Jobs.ta: This is a core tool at Web Apps Actualized, and reduces the use of VCR.js down to a list of functions that act on a container.

Languages.ta: I used HTACCESS to make a library version manager. I call it a 'library pipe', where projects can override the default version of a library.

Projects.ta: The Site Generator was written in the file system manager's application renderer.
The Daily Wizard was built with the application renderer included with the file system manager
The database manager was built in the file system manager's application engine
